content: First, the sending of messages is neither IMAP nor POP; instead, it is SMTP. It may help to post a screenshot of the SMTP server pane so readers here see exactly what thunderbird sees. My guess (and it's only that), is that authentication needs to be other than 'no authentication.' Try 'normal password.' Also, be sure to use the full email address, not just the prefix.
creator: davidsk

content: Mark those messages accidentally marked as spam as 'Not Spam'. Also see https://support.mozilla.org/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages
creator: christ1

content:
christ1 said
Mark those messages accidentally marked as spam as 'Not Spam'. Also see https://support.mozilla.org/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages

That worked nice and easy. Thanks.

I thought that by marking spam emails from the worst offenders I was training the adaptive filter, and that when I clicked on "Run Spam Controls" it would scan and auto-tag those same offending domains as spam for in the entire inbox of 4,000+ emails, instead it tagged every email as spam. I won't be doing that again.
creator: Xenu

content:
With the Yahoo account, it appears to be a cookie issue. Cookies must be accepted in TB (not browser) Settings/Privacy & Security for the OAuth2 authentication to complete.

With the gmail account, you'll have to be more specific, i.e. state the error message when you try to connect. Some issues can be caused by external factors like antivirus or VPN.

content:
If you are on Windows and use a Thunderbird 140 esr or a Thunderbird release version beneath v147 you can install the add-on "ImportExportTools NG" https://services.addons.thunderbird.net/EN-us/thunderbird/addon/importexporttools-ng/ which allows to export messages in the .pdf format (image)

Probably you'll have to save attachments and send them to your bank separately, together with the corresponding .pdf message export files.

content: Thank you very much David. Now if I can just stop all this junk from showing up, but that's not going to happen. There's too much money being made selling email addresses to third parties.
creator: joseph-rowland

content: i was glad to assist. I personally use the free copy of Mailwasher (it's free for one email account) and it does an excellent job of remember all the email addresses I don't like. Most junk arrives overnight, so I run mailwasher first thing in the morning to clear the junk out. You might also check to see if your email provider uses Spamassasin, as thunderbird can use that to further trash the junk. And, I don't know if it's true, but I've read that unsubscribing just makes it worse. But it's hard to verify such advice. Good luck.
creator: davidsk

content:
I would say that "Unsubscribe" in general only really works for legitimate business senders, who probably wouldn't be spamming you with lots of junk email. Most of them (not all!) are smart enough to stay on the right side of the line between advertising and annoying their customers.

If you closely examine the headers and embedded links in an email, you can usually judge whether the sender is legit or not. But if you're not sure and you don't want to spend the time and effort, I recommend you NEVER use the UNSUBSCRIBE feature. If it's a spammer, it will not stop the spam and it will just tell them that they now have a valuable valid email address that they can sell to others.

I find that junk email goes in cycles. For a while I'll get a ton of it, then it ramps down, stays quiet for a while, then cycles up again. I imagine overseas spam farms whose customers buy limited time campaigns. The campaigns are often for seemingly different "products" but are similar in format and tone. Despite some complaints I see here, Thunderbird's Bayesian spam filter does a decent job of catching most of them, and more is caught by my custom filters. So, it never goes away, but I can keep it manageable.
creator: rednoise

content: If you have any prior profiles, there may be an older copy you could salvage. the names are abook.sqlite and history.sqlite. click help>troubleshootinginformation, scroll to 'profiles' and click 'about:profiles' and then click the 'open folder' for any inactive profiles to see if the abook.sqlite file is there and shows that it has had some maintenance. If so, you could copy and paste into the active profile after closing thunderbird. OR, there is an addon, Mail extractor, that can search you message folder and extract email addresses from prior contacts and create a csv file that can be imported to the addressbook. this wouldn't solve all your concerns, but would rebuild somewhat. Otherwise, the file is gone.
creator: davidsk

content:
The Address Book files are located in your Profile folder and have names like "abook.sqlite". The Address Book window has an Import button. If you have a backup of your address book files or, even better, your entire profile, you can import the backup into your working Thunderbird installation.

If you deleted the address book outside of Thunderbird, maybe they're in your system's trash folder? If not, and you don't have a backup, you're out of luck - that address book is gone for good.

If you have other similar address books, say, in Google, they can be imported into Thunderbird, so all may not be lost.
creator: rednoise

content:
l may be missing your intent, but I still believe your challenge is that you are composing in plain text mode. In plain text mode, the 'insert' option does not appear on the toolbar. You either need to press the shift key when clicking 'new message' or set the account to compose in HTML at 'account settings' and then in 'composition & addressing.' If this is wrong, please let me know.

Also, although your questions are always welcome, please try to stay within the original thread for continuity. That ensures that the original question is still there, so others who read the forum may be able to also offer suggestions. I do hope we can eventually resolve this for you. Thank you. david
creator: davidsk

content: Which is the "recommended procedure to transfer the TB profile" you followed? On the new Win11 computer go to Help > Troubleshooting information > Profile Folder > Open Folder, then quit Thunderbird. In the profile folder go the Mail > Local Folders and make a screen shot of its contents. Also go to Account Settings > Local Folders > Message Storage > Local Directory and make make a screen shot of the path to the local directory of Local folders....

creator: vetterlein

content:
The error message might be incomplete or misleading. Besides the user ID and password, it could be an incorrect server name or other settings. If all of your snet accounts are with the same service (it looks like that domain has been passed around various companies over the years,) make note of the Server Settings for the working accounts, in particular, the server name and port, and the security settings.

If you're using it, turn OFF Thunderbird's "experimental" Account Hub feature. It works for most people, but sometimes it chooses wrong settings. If off, you should be able to manually enter settings that will hopefully work better.

Otherwise, see if you can find your mail host's official recommended settings and compare to what you're trying to use.
creator: rednoise
